result.execSummary:
The defendant Joshua M. Uhing was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Manufacture/Deliver Cocaine (<=1g), a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(cm)1g.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Arresting Agency: JCSD

If probation, parole or extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of the victim(s) and government entities for the balance due.

supervisions.notes:
The Court sentences Joshua Uhing to 8 years, with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of 3 years, and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 5 years, consecutive to any sentence in being.  
The Court gives 458 days credit for time already served.

**Per Court's 6/28/21 Order: Sentence Credit amended to '459' days**
The Court finds that the Defendant is eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program "Boot Camp".
The Court finds that the Defendant is eligible for the Substance Abuse Program.

--to undergo any other assessment, treatment or counseling as deemed appropriate by the Agent

--no contact with any known drug offender except for treatment purposes as deemed appropriate per Agent
--random drug and/or alcohol screening (at least once per month for first 3 months, thereafter per Agent)

supervisions.notes: The Court adopts the previously ordered conditions of to now be conditions of extended supervision: [Clerks note  per DOC records, the previously ordered financial obligations ordered by the Court were paid through DOC prior to revocation.]

records.addlTxt:
[NL] cases 15CF125 and 16CF325 called briefly at 11:04 am and again at 11:15 am 
Defendant Joshua M. Uhing in court with attorney Anthony C. Delyea.  Defendant Joshua M. Uhing in custody.   ADA Monica Hall appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
 
Attorney Delyea submits a packet of documents regarding possible programming and give sentence arguments 
Sentencing arguments given by ADA Hall 
Statement given by Mr. Uhing

As to 15CF125 Count #1
The Court sentences Joshua Uhing to 8 years, with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of 3 years, and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 5 years, consecutive to any sentence in being.  
The Court gives 458 days credit for time already served.


The Court finds that the Defendant is eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program "Boot Camp".
The Court finds that the Defendant is eligible for the Substance Abuse Program.

The Court adopts the previously ordered conditions of to now be conditions of extended supervision:
[those conditions are
--to undergo AODA assessment and follow through with recommended treatment
--to undergo any other assessment, treatment or counseling as deemed appropriate by the Agent
--random drug and/or alcohol screening (at least once per month for first 3 months, thereafter per Agent)
--to obtain/maintain employment and/or education program as approved by the Agent
--no possession of controlled substance without a valid prescription
--no contact with any known drug offender except for treatment purposes as deemed appropriate per Agent
--to pay Drug Testing Fee in the amount of $75
--to pay Buy Money Reimbursement in the amount of $180
--to pay Subpoena Fees in the amount of $33
--to pay costs of $268 plus the $250 DNA surcharge]

As to 16CF325 Count #1
The Court sentences the Defendant to pay costs, this amount is to be entered as a civil judgment.

As to 16CF325 Count #2 
The Court sentences the Defendant to pay costs, this amount is to be entered as a civil judgment.

NEXT: Sentencing After Revocation/Sentencing on 5/30/17 at 11:30am
Sentencing hearing on revocation on May 23, 2017 at 03:00 pm.

[MK; no record made]
Defendant Joshua M. Uhing in court, in custody.  ADA Theresa Beck appears for the State of Wisconsin.
Case #15CF125 is scheduled for Sentencing After Revocation and Case #16CF325 was scheduled for Sentencing today at 1:15pm. The DOC Agent was present at the 1:15 scheduled time.
Shortly before the scheduled 1:15pm hearing time an email was received from Attorney Delyea saying that he had a travel delay, but that Attorney Delyea would go to his office, get Mr. Uhing's file, and that it would take more than an hour to travel.    
The Court's clerk telephoned and left voicemails at 2:55pm for Attorney Delyea, inquiring about his timing and asking for an update on his anticipated arrival-time.  Attorney Delyea telephoned back shortly thereafter to say that he was at his office and could leave and arrive in court in approximately 35 minutes.   
The Court directed its staff to reschedule the hearing.  The JA discussed rescheduling with Attorney Delyea to set a date when he has availability.   

NEXT:  reschedule Case #15CF125 for Sentencing After Revocation and Case #16CF325 for Sentencing, both on 5/23/17 at 3:00pm.

Huber Law/Work Release Notification

Case called at 1:08pm [mo]
Defendant Joshua M. Uhing in court with Attorney David P. Geraghty.   DA Susan Happ appears for the State of Wisconsin.
  
Maximum penalties recited; Constitutional rights reviewed; plea of " Guilty " entered on Count #1 without the 2nd or subsequent enhancer; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified; the Court accepts the plea, finds Defendant guilty, and orders Judgment of Conviction entered.

On Motion of the State, the Court reads-in and dismisses Counts #2 and #3

Sentencing arguments given by Counsel 
Statement made by Mr. Uhing

On Count #1: The Court withholds sentence and places Mr. Uhing on Probation for a term of 24 months, with the following conditions:

--to serve 5 months in the Jefferson County Jail, with work-release privileges, to commence on  12/7/15 at   7:00     pm.
--The Defendant is ordered to report and serve the sentence with absolute sobriety and without illegal drugs in his system; failure to comply will result in loss of Huber/work release without further process.
--to undergo AODA assessment and follow through with recommended treatment
--to undergo any other assessment, treatment or counseling as deemed appropriate by the Agent
--random drug and/or alcohol screening (at least once per month for first 3 months, thereafter per Agent)
--to obtain/maintain employment and/or education program as approved by the Agent
--no possession of controlled substance without a valid prescription
--no contact with any known drug offender except for treatment purposes as deemed appropriate per Agent
--to pay Drug Testing Fee in the amount of $75
--to pay Buy Money Reimbursement in the amount of $180
--to pay Subpoena Fees in the amount of $33
--to pay costs of $268 plus the $250 DNA surcharge


Days credit for time already served:  0  days
Felony Firearm/Voting Prohibition Warnings given
recess: 1:49pm
Criminal case settlement agreement form - endorsed by the defendant and the attorney.

Case called at 3:59pm.  Clerk - CRHI. 
Defendant Joshua M. Uhing in court with attorney David P. Geraghty.  Susan Victoria Happ appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Victim rights compliance verified and so found. 
Defense acknowledges the prior convictions sited in the motion filed by the State.  Defense position is that the defendant should indicate 6 prior convictions should he testify. 
Atty. Geraghty informs the Court that an agreement has been reached in this case and requests that the FSSC be used for as a Plea Hearing. 
In response to an inquiry by the Court, the State requests that the number of priors to be set at 7 should the defendant elect to testify; presents basis. 
Court finds all of the convictions listed to be valid and of record. Court finds the number of priors that can be used to impeach the defendant should he elect to tesify to be 5; presents basis. 
Case continued as scheduled.
